facts.text: This appeal is directed against the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge of the Kerala High Court

facts.text: An election was held on 29.4.2006 to the Kerala Legislative Assembly from No.67 Kodungalloor Assembly Constituency

anchor.surface_text: Brief facts which are necessary for disposal of this appeal are that an election was held on 29.4.2006 to the Kerala Legislative Assembly from No.67 Kodungalloor Assembly Constituency. It was alleged in the election petition

facts.text: The appellant filed election petition alleging that the election be declared void on the ground of corrupt practice committed either by the respondents election agent or by some other person with the consent of the respondent or his election agent

arguments.claim: Following precedent: defects in verification not fatal (Murarka Radhey Shyam)

anchor.surface_text: The first is Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors.  1964 3 SCR 573 . In this case with regard to the defect in the verification, this Court observed as follows We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do number think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect

arguments.claim: S83 non-compliance may lead to O6 R15/O7 R11 dismissal but defects curable (H.D. Revanna)

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, in H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors.  1999  2 SCC 217, it was observed as follows The provisions in the Representation of the People Act, 1951 are very specific. Section 86 provides for dismissal of an election petition in limine for number-compliance with Sections 81, 82 and 117.

arguments.claim: Election petitions not to be summarily dismissed on minor procedural breaches; strict construction but substance matters

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the election petition has to be seriously companystrued. But that apart the election petition should number be summarily dismissed on such small breaches of procedure.

holdings.text: The defects in the affidavit in Form 25, including lack of proper affirmation certification and source disclosure, are minor and do not warrant dismissal of the election petition.

anchor.surface_text: I, Umesh Challiyill, aged 45 years, S o CA Krishnan, Challiyil House, Arakulam West, Kodungalloor, the petitioner in the accompanying election petition calling in question the election of Shri K P Rajendran  respondent in the said petition  make solemn affirmation and say-  a  that the statements made in paragraphs 1, 2 and 4 of the accompanying election petition about the commission of corrupt practice of putting up the poster as seen in the photograph Annexure A and the publication and distribution of Annexures C and D

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defects in notary certification are of very minor nature, bona fide mistake, conveys sense of solemn affirmation, does not go to root of matter.

holdings.text: The verification of the election petition is not defective as it conveys the same meaning and substance as required under CPC Order VI Rule 15 and Form 25, despite not using exact words like 'true'.

anchor.surface_text: After going through the affidavit filed by the appellant and the format of the concluding portion of the affidavit, we fail to appreciate that in what way the verification can be found to be bad except that it has not used the word, true it is expressed in other way, no part thereof is false and nothing which is relevant has been concealed. Instead of saying, true it has been put up in other way round, no part thereof is false and nothing which is relevant has been concealed, which conveys the same meaning as was used, I believe the same to be true.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phraseology 'no part thereof is false' conveys same as 'true to knowledge/information'; substance and essence conveyed; not fatal defect.

holdings.text: Defects under Section 83 do not entail mandatory dismissal under Section 86, which applies only to non-compliance with Sections 81, 82 or 117.

anchor.surface_text: Section 86 says that the High Court shall dismiss the election petition which does not comply with the provisions of Section 81 or Section 82 or Section 117. But none of defect of the nature as pointed out by the respondent would entail dismissal of the election petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of S86 excludes S83; supported by precedents like H.D. Revanna.

holdings.text: Minor defects in verification and affidavit of election petitions alleging corrupt practices are curable, do not go to the root, and do not warrant summary dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: After going through the affidavit filed by the appellant and the format of the concluding portion of the affidavit, we fail to appreciate that in what way the verification can be found to be bad except that it has not used the word, true... It is true that the election petition has to be strictly construed. But that apart the election petition should not be summarily dismissed on such small breaches of procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts must view if objections go to root or cosmetic; substance over form; precedents like Murarka Radhey Shyam hold such defects not fatal.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in dismissing the petition without giving opportunity to cure defects; court should direct amendment before dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: In case, learned Single Judge found that the election petition was not in the format then after recording his finding, learned Single Judge should have given an opportunity to the appellant to amend or cure certain defects pointed out by the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural fairness requires notice and chance to rectify even if defects found; appellant bona fide believed petition complete; supported by CPC rules.

holdings.text: Non-compliance with S83 may lead to dismissal under Order VII R11 or Order VI R16/17 CPC only after failure to cure defects upon opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: but since the election petition could be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11, in case of petitioners failure to furnish any of the material facts... the Court should give proper opportunity to cure the defects and in case of failure to remove cure the defects, it could result into dismissal on account of Order 6 Rule 17 or Order 7 Rule 11 CPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous application of CPC provisions; opportunity under O6 R17 before rejection under O7 R11; distinguished from cases of persistent non-cure.

holdings.text: The order dated 6.12.2006 of the Kerala High Court Single Judge dismissing the election petition is set aside and matter remitted for proceeding with the petition.

anchor.surface_text: the view taken by learned Single Judge of the High Court is not correct and we set aside the order dated 6.12.2006 passed by the learned Single Judge in P.No.6 of 2006 and remit this matter back to the High Court of Kerala

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of above findings on defects being minor/curable and lack of opportunity; defects do not go to root.

precedents.citation: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors. 1964 3 SCR 573

anchor.surface_text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore Ors. 1964 3 SCR 573 . In this case with regard to the defect in the verification, this Court observed as follows We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do number think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition.

precedents.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v Roop Singh Rathore
precedents.cited_proposition: defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is not such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition; other minor defects like improper copies or missing signatures do not warrant dismissal
precedents.cited_holding: We agree with the view expressed by the Election Tribunal and we do number think that the defect in the verification due to inexperience of the Oaths Commissioner is such a fatal defect as to require the dismissal of the election petition.

precedents.citation: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors. 1999 2 SCC 217

anchor.surface_text: H.D.Revanna v. G.Puttaswamy Gowda Ors. 1999 2 SCC 217, it was observed as follows The provisions in the Representation of the People Act, 1951 are very specific. Section 86 provides for dismissal of an election petition in limine for number-compliance with Sections 81, 82 and 117.

precedents.case_name: H D Revanna v G Puttaswamy Gowda
precedents.cited_proposition: non-compliance with Section 83 does not lead to automatic dismissal under Section 86; defects in verification of election petition or accompanying affidavit are curable and not fatal
precedents.cited_holding: Defect in verification of the election petition or the affidavit accompanying the election petition has been held to be curable and number fatal

precedents.citation: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors. 2004 11 SCC 196

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v. Sukh Darshan Singh Ors. 2004 11 SCC 196, this Court held as follows In the present case, the grounds of companyrupt practice and the facts necessary to formulate a companyplete cause of action had been stated.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Harcharan Singh Brar v Sukh Darshan Singh
precedents.cited_proposition: deficiency in particulars of corrupt practice cannot be ground for dismissing election petition at threshold; petitioner can be directed to supply particulars
precedents.cited_holding: deficiency in particulars companyld number have been a ground for dismissing the petition at the threshold

precedents.citation: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986 Supp. SCC 315

anchor.surface_text: Azhar Hussain v. Rajiv Gandhi 1986 Supp. SCC 315. There also this Court held that though Section 83 is number mentioned in Section 86, but since the election petition companyld be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11

precedents.cited_proposition: election petition can be summarily dismissed under Order 6 Rule 16 or Order 7 Rule 11 CPC for failure to furnish material facts and particulars essential for cause of action in corrupt practice allegations
precedents.cited_holding: The dismissal of the election petition is number on account of Section 83 but on account of failure of companypliance of Order 6 Rule 16 and Order 7 Rule 11, CPC.

precedents.citation: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors. 2005 2 SCC 188

anchor.surface_text: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v. Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar Ors. 2005 2 SCC 188, it was held that where the defects in companyies were curable number-vital in nature the election petition cannot be dismissed at the threshold for number-compliance with Section 81 3  on the basis of such defects.

precedents.case_name: Chandrakant Uttam Chodankar v Dayanand Rayu Mandrakar
precedents.cited_proposition: curable and non-vital defects in copies do not warrant dismissal of election petition at threshold for non-compliance with Section 81(3)

precedents.citation: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc. 2003 1 SCC 289

anchor.surface_text: Ram Prasad Sarma v. Mani Kumar Subba Ors. Etc. 2003 1 SCC 289, it was held that verification in support of the allegations of companyrupt practice accompanying the petition by Oath Commissioner was number integral part of the petition.

precedents.case_name: Ram Prasad Sarma v Mani Kumar Subba
precedents.cited_proposition: absence of stamp and name of Oath Commissioner in true copy of affidavit does not amount to vital deviation; verification not integral part warranting dismissal

precedents.citation: R.P.Moidutty v. P.T.Kunju Mohammad Anr. 2000 1 SCC 481

anchor.surface_text: R.P.Moidutty v. P.T.Kunju Mohammad Anr. 2000 1 SCC 481 their Lordships have expressed that heavy onus lies on the election petitioner seeking setting aside of the election of a successful candidate

precedents.case_name: R P Moidutty v P T Kunju Mohammad
precedents.cited_proposition: defect in verification is curable but if petitioner persists without rectification after objection, petition cannot be tried; should be rejected at threshold for non-compliance with pleadings requirements
precedents.cited_holding: the defect of verification is number fatal to the petition, it can be cured

anchor.surface_text: A.Sapa v. Singora the object of requiring verification of an election petition is to clearly fix the responsibility for the averments and allegations in the petition on the person signing the verification and, at the same time, discouraging wild and irresponsible allegations unsupported by facts.

precedents.cited_proposition: object of verification is to fix responsibility for averments and discourage wild allegations; defect in verification is not fatal and can be cured

precedents.citation: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore

anchor.surface_text: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v. Roop Singh Rathore and A.S.Subbaraj v. M. Muthiah  . In the present case the defect in verification was pointed out by raising a plea in that regard in the written statement.

precedents.case_name: Murarka Radhey Shyam Ram Kumar v Roop Singh Rathore

anchor.surface_text: A.S.Subbaraj v. M. Muthiah  . In the present case the defect in verification was pointed out by raising a plea in that regard in the written statement. The objection was pressed and pursued by arguing the same before the Court.

precedents.case_name: A S Subbaraj v M Muthiah
